title: Imaging
text:
Diving into imaging is a great experience. I have engaged in many imaging techniques, including light, fluorescence, laser scanning microscopy, as part of my work. I find immense joy in appreciating the aesthetic aspects of biology through the art of imaging.









Sperm of Platynereis dumerilii labeled in orange (nuclei) and olive (standard lissaminated morpholino).







Male and female of Platynereis dumerili. Associated article and cover page in Development: Ribeiro et al. 2025.







This is a photo of a regenerated anterior body of Syllis malaquini. In pink, S-phase cells, i.e. proliferating cells. Green: chaetae. Associated research article: Ribeiro et al. 2021.








Sperm of Platynereis dumerilii labeled in orange (nuclei) and olive (standard lissaminated morpholino).
Male and female of Platynereis dumerili. Associated article and cover page in Development: Ribeiro et al. 2025.
This is a photo of a regenerated anterior body of Syllis malaquini. In pink, S-phase cells, i.e. proliferating cells. Green: chaetae. Associated research article: Ribeiro et al. 2021.

title: Comics - Wormly Speaking
text:
Comics are a fun and versatile way to communicate complex ideas. As a comic enthusiast, I began illustrating them to share my research findings. I’ve crafted comic strips for some of my scientific publications, blending storytelling with science in an engaging format. Rather than following a rigid publishing schedule, I allow my creativity and current mindset to shape the scientific narratives I bring to life.
Expanding on this passion, I launched Wormly Speaking—a project dedicated to giving voice to the fascinating yet often overlooked polychaete worms. Through this channel, my mission is to empower and inspire us with hopeful stories while also sharing the remarkable traits of these worms, such as their reproduction styles and ability to regenerate. These worms have been my role model of resilience during hard transitional times in my life. Take a peek at the stories I’ve created so far— they may be hopeful worms for you too!
Follow Wormly Speaking: https://www.instagram.com/wormlyspeaking/

Syllis in Wonderland - Part II. Syllis versus The Queen of Hearts!









We named a polychete species in honor to Zelinha (Maurizelia de Brito) - the guardian of the paradisiacal Rocas Atoll. Thanks Zelinha. Details in Freitas et al. (2023).







We named a polychaete species in honor to my first PI, Dr. Zafira de Almeida. Unfortunately, she left us so soon and I miss her so much. She will continue to be one of my role models. Thanks, Za. Details in Freitas et al. (2022)









A new Ramisyllis from Japan. It clearly deserves a comic, and it will be a new friend for Syllis. Details in Aguado et al. (2022).







I described a new syllid species and it was the inspiration for my first comic character, Syllis. Details in Ribeiro et al (2020)

title: New publication on regeneration
text:
Publication alert!! Today we published another paper on regeneration. This time we made many experiments to discover how many segments Syllis malaquini needs to regenerate the whole-body. We found that this species needs three segments to complete both anterior and posterior regeneration, but with just two segments it already regenerates at least the head and the tail. That’s amazing! Check it out: https://doi.org/10.1111/ede.12492, Evolution & Development.
Syllis malaquini is a species of marine segmented worm that we found in an aquarium. Since then, we keep the worms in an aquarium reproducing mostly by asexual architomic fission. Details on our first publication on this worm: https://doi.org/10.1007/s12526-020-01046-y

title: Highlights from the EuroEvoDevo 2024
text: I attended to the EuroEvoDevo Meeting in Helsinki, Finland this month. The event was fantastic, offering the chance to reconnect with friends and colleagues and make new connections. It was a wonderful opportunity to share the results of my first postdoc project. I presented at the Platynereis Satellite Meeting and the Symposium “Diversity of Sex Determination Mechanisms” during the EuroEvoDevo 2024.

title: Germ Cells 2024 - CSHL
text: This was my first time attending the Germ Cells Meeting at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, and I enjoyed every moment. I am returning home with many wonderful memories and valuable insights gained from this remarkable community of researchers. A highlight was the opportunity to toast with the 2024 Nobel Prize winners in Physiology and Medicine via videoconference, which added a special touch to the event. Also, I loved these cute Halloween decorations!

title: Genetic Models at Janelia Research Campus
text: Today was the last day of the Conference Genetic Tools for New Model Organisms. I am so grateful for the opportunity to attend this amazing conference, network and meet so many smart and inspiring people revolutionazing techniques to study the diversity of model organisms. I learned a lot about genome editing and I presented a poster about a technique for gene knock down I have been working on during my postdoc. It was a great conference in an amazing institute. Simply unforgettable!

title: Undegraduate symposium
text: Today, my mentee Kaitlyn presented our research at the Fall Undergraduate Symposium, and I couldn’t be more thrilled and proud of her achievement. This event is a fantastic opportunity for undergrad students to showcase their research experience and gain some communication skills. Congrats, Kaitlyn!

title: Undergrad accomplishments
text: Mia Somocurcio, a visiting undergraduate student in the Özpolat Lab whom I am currently mentoring, has been accepted to attend an international course at the University of Salamanca. Congrats Mia!

title: Invited talk for Gonomix
text: I gave a seminar for Gönomix, a group of researchers from the University of Göttingen studying the diversity of gene function in development and other biological processes. I took a course on Molecular Genetics there five years ago and it was great to see some of my professors and the campus once again. My talk was about sexual differentiation in Platynereis dumerilii.

title: The Node behind the paper story
text: Check out “Tiny titans: fantastic worms and their powerful regenerative abilities” - a Behind the Paper story I published today in The Node. I’m thrilled to contribute to this initiative, which I have been following for a long time. I love everything about science communication from The Company of Biologists, and I look forward to contributing more in the future!

title: 2025 National Postdoctoral Association Annual Meeting
text: After Janelia, I was awarded another exciting opportunity—this time to present my outreach work as a member and 2023–2024 leader of the WashU Postdoctoral Society. Alongside Sandhya Tripathi, PhD, we showcased the initiatives of the Outreach Committee through print media and events we organized. We also led a 60-minute workshop for about 20 attendees, where we discussed programs like the Rapid Fire Round, our podcast, and Brews and Brains, among other initiatives. More about our outreach on WUPS website.

title: Research
text:
Syllis malaquini, anterior regeneration (Ribeiro et al 2021)


Ranny studies regeneration and reproduction in marine segmented worms, also known as annelids. During her PhD, she investigated the relationship between regeneration and reproduction under an evolutionary perspective. Using diverse tools such as RNA sequencing, bioinformatics, and immunohistochemistry, she characterized cellular proliferation and the transcriptomic profile of anterior and posterior body regeneration in a specific group of annelids called syllids. Currently, her postdoctoral research is focused on understanding how these organisms regenerate there germ cells, and the dynamics of germ cell differentiation. Annelids stand out from other highly regenerative organisms like planarians and cnidarians due to the absence of specialized stem cells dedicated to regeneration. This absence raises an intriguing question: how do they achieve remarkable regenerative feats without relying on specific cell types? Unraveling this mystery holds the potential to manipulate regenerative processes in various cell types, including those found in vertebrates.

title: Research
text:
Syllis malaquini, anterior regeneration (Ribeiro et al 2021)


Ranny studies regeneration and reproduction in marine segmented worms, also known as annelids. During her PhD, she investigated the relationship between regeneration and reproduction under an evolutionary perspective. Using diverse tools such as RNA sequencing, bioinformatics, and immunohistochemistry, she characterized cellular proliferation and the transcriptomic profile of anterior and posterior body regeneration in a specific group of annelids called syllids. Currently, her postdoctoral research is focused on understanding how these organisms regenerate there germ cells, and the dynamics of germ cell differentiation. Annelids stand out from other highly regenerative organisms like planarians and cnidarians due to the absence of specialized stem cells dedicated to regeneration. This absence raises an intriguing question: how do they achieve remarkable regenerative feats without relying on specific cell types? Unraveling this mystery holds the potential to manipulate regenerative processes in various cell types, including those found in vertebrates.

title: Research
text:
Annelid diversity and evolution



Syllis malaquini (Ribeiro et al 2020)


Ranny has devoted many years to studying the diversity of annelids Embarking on her scientific journey by collecting specimens from the mangroves of her hometown, São Luís (MA), Brazil, her initial venture into science involved taxonomical description of new species. Having overseen two projects for Bachelors and a Masters degree, and through collaborative research set alongside, she has described 15 annelid species. Furthermore, her expertise in taxonomy has facilitated her contributions to ecology, particularly in evaluating environmental health within both impacted and preserved marine ecosystems.

title: New Paper on the Cover of Development! 🪱✨
text:
How do worms make eggs and sperm? In our latest study in the Özpolat Lab, we uncover the transcriptional signatures of gametogenesis in the segmented worm Platynereis dumerilii. Using RNA-seq, we show how sex-biased gene expression—including dmrt1 and a newly identified gene, psmt—emerges as worms mature. Our work provides new tools for sex identification and lays the groundwork for exploring germ cell evolution. And guess what.. we got the cover!
📄 Read more in Development: Ribeiro et al. 2025.

title: CRM Seed Grant - Junior Innovator Award
text:
Today, I was thrilled to receive a seed grant to support my research on highly regenerative animal models! The journey to this achievement was both exciting and rewarding. I was selected as one of the five finalists and had the opportunity to present my pitch at a fun and engaging event. I’m proud to share that I was awarded $15,000 for my research. This marks my first grant, and I couldn’t be more excited about this milestone!
I’m also incredibly happy for my friend and colleague, Yu Seon Kim, PhD, who is also a member of the WUPS Outreach Committee with me. Together with Yu Seon we made top two in the competition. It was a fantastic experience to celebrate this achievement together. Also, a huge thank you to Yu Seon for capturing the moment with a photo.
My sincere acknowledgments to my mentors, Dr. Duygu Özpolat and Dr. Kerry Kornfeld andall the members of the Özpolat Lab for their invaluable feedback, which played a fundamental role in helping me deliver a strong and impactful presentation.
This grant is just the beginning, and I’m excited to see where this research takes us next!



Ranny Ribeiro presenting a research pitch at the CRM Innovator Challenge competition. Photo by Yu Seon Kim.

title: Talk at Stowers Institute
text: Today, I had the privilege of presenting my research during the Stowers Research Conference on Developmental Cell Biology. In this research, I explored sex differences during gametogenesis in Platynereis dumerilii using RNA sequencing. We uncovered that sex-biased gene expression becomes more pronounced during advanced developmental stages. Learn more about the novel genes we discovered and explore our pre-print for additional details.

title: Talk in the CRM Retreat 2024
text: Today I delivered a talk for the 2024 DRSCB/DB/CRM Joint Retreat, Washington University in St. Louis. I love this annual event and I was so excited to share this piece of my research… I am already looking forward to next year’s retreat!

title: Welcome To My Website
text:
Welcome to my website! Here, you’ll discover my research on amazing worms that can regrow their whole bodies. I’ll also share my latest adventures in teaching, outreach, and sci-art. Let the journey begin, and may you find it both informative and enjoyable!

Anterior regeneration in Syllis malaquini. Green, chaetae. Pink, S-phase cells.

title: Kaitlyn secured a pre-med intership for this Summer!
text: I am so happy to share that Kaitlyn has recently been accepted as an intern in the Northwestern Medicine Pre-Med Internship Program. I have been mentoring her for the past 2 years and she is such an outstanding pre-med student. Congrats, Kaitlyn!

title: CRM award
text: I’m thrilled. I was awarded the Center for Regenerative Medicine Distinguished (CRM) Postdoctoral Scholars fellowship. This is a program for career development led by CRM with the mission “to develop highly trained individuals who can produce impactful research in regenerative medicine through an interdisciplinary training plan”. Click here to know more about this program.

title: Ranny co-hosts a podcast
text: The WUPS Outreach Committee just started another project: WUPS podcast… and I’m co-hosting it. In our inaugural episode, hosted by the brilliatn scientist Dr. Rishabh Bajpai, we had the pleasure of interviewing Dr. Ash Rajesh. We delved into her impactful research, her achievements and experiences as the current president of WUPS, and gained insight into her personal journey. Tune in and check it out here: WUPS podcast.

title: New pre-print
text: We published a pre-print about sex differentiation in Platynereis dumerilii! This was such a cool experiment! “Sex-biased gene expression precedes sexual dimorphism in the agonadal annelid Platynereis” https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.06.12.598746v1

title: Bio
text:
Rannyele Passos Ribeiro


Education
PhD. in Biology. Autonomous University of Madrid, Spain. 2021.
MSc. in Environmental Sciences and Conservation. Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. 2015.
BSc. in Biology. State University of Maranhão, Brazil. 2013.
More information on my CV.


Biography
I come from São Luís, Maranhão, Brazil, with a diverse heritage that includes Native Brazilian ancestry from the Guajajara tribe, as well as African and Iberian roots. My interest in science began at a young age, and I eventually became a biologist. During my undergraduate studies, I was introduced to a remarkable realm inhabited by creatures both delicate and conspicuous—polychaete annelids, which are marine segmented worms. I have navigated through various projects studying these worms, spanning taxonomy, ecology, reproduction, and ultimately, regeneration. Sometimes my adventures led me to the middle of a mangrove, collecting worms from the mud; sometimes, I found myself scuba diving in paradisiacal oceanic islands, and most times, I was on the lab bench, pipetting or counting segments.
Each adventure has contributed to my understanding of how amazing these worms are. Fascinated by their remarkable regenerative abilities, my research has become a quest to comprehend the mechanisms by which their cells proliferate and differentiate. Additionally, I am continually amazed by how these mechanisms enable these worms to defy the passage of time and live indefinitely. Ultimately, they inspired me to start a sci-art project to communicate my findings using comics.
While I enjoy my work, I prioritize a balanced lifestyle by spending quality time with my family and friends, and maintaining a fitness routine for strength. Having hobbies is essential for me, and aside from playing guitar for enjoyment, I immerse myself in my love for dancing. I enjoy exploring diverse dance styles such as salsa, bachata, kizomba, as well as Brazilian styles like forró, axé and more.


How to pronounce my name
I go by Ranny, pronounced as “hun-ny”.

title: Rannyele P. Ribeiro, PhD
text: I am currently a Postdoctoral Researcher in the Özpolat Lab at Washington University in St. Louis. My primary research interest lies in exploring regeneration in segmented worms. Regeneration served as a key factor in my current project, which focuses on uncovering sex-biased differences in the segmented worm Platyneries dumerilii, using RNA sequencing.

title: Outreach
text:
Ranny is an active member of both the Outreach Committee and the Career Development Committee of the WashU Postdoctoral Society. She has contributed to various initiatives, including the Table Topics, Rapid Fire Round and the WUPS Podcast.


The WUPS Outreach Committee launched a series of interviews with postdocs to showcase their work and value during Ranny’s tenure as Outreach Director of the WashU Postdoc Society (WUPS) from 2023 to 2024. These interviews aim to inform a broader audience, including our own families, about the role and significance of postdocs. Personally, I was inspired by my grandparents, who still think I am a student. They’re not entirely wrong, as being a scientist is a lifelong journey of learning and producing knowledge—an invaluable product!
To access our interviews, please visit the Rapid Fire Round.



Expanding on the goals of the Rapid Fire Round, the WUPS Outreach Committee introduced a podcast. In this new format, we interview postdocs, faculty members, and other researchers to discuss science in both audio and video formats. The podcast is hosted by Dr. Rishabh Bajpai, with Ranny and other Outreach Committee members contributing to tasks such as developing questions and advertising. Check it out here: WUPS podcast.

title: Resources
text:
I like to employ different strategies for teaching. Recently, I took advantage of the flipped classroom concept and I developed some course material based on gamification. I think it is an effective approach for teaching and learning. I have crafted some resources for classes of Embryology, Zoology, English in three languages (Portuguese, Spanish and English). I used the platform Genially to build these games. I absolutely recommend it. Also, I published a article about my experience using some the series “Gamizoo” during lab course of Zoology.

Find the pairs. Embryology Course. [English]
Gamizoo Bivalvos. Zoology course. [Spanish]
Gamizoo Insectos. Zoology course. [Spanish]
Hobbying. English course. [Portuguese]
Gamizoo Aves de Navaseca. Zoology course.[Spanish]
Gamizoo Aves. Zoology course. [Spanish]

title: Resources
text:
Bioinformatics and coding resources
Helpful resources I utilize in Bioinformatics are accessible through my GitHub account.
I created this website using Quarto, which is straightforward to manage when you are familiar with RStudio and R coding. The theme used is flatly.

title: Resources
text:
Mental Health and Professional Development
I believe that overall health should be our priority. Initially, the academic environment may pose challenges such as job insecurity, making it difficult to persevere and build resilience. Access to medical care and self-help resources is crucial. Here’s a list of my favorite resources that help me stay resilient, including books and videos. Stoicism is my lifestyle philosophy!

Letters from a Stoic, by Seneca
Meditations, by Marcus Aurelius
Amar, desamar, amar de novo, by Marcos Lacerda.
Amar-se, uma viagem em busca de si mesmo, by Marcos Lacerda.
ASMR videos. This is an amazing relaxation technique. I super recommend it.
About Mental Health.
